commit.message:
feat(go.mod): add pulumi-command SDK dependency for enhanced infrastructure management capabilities

The addition of the pulumi-command SDK allows for improved management of
infrastructure as code, enabling more robust deployment and
configuration options within the project.

feat: add Pulumi setup for Azure resource management

- Add Pulumi configuration file for development environment with encryption salt and Azure location set to southeastasia
- Add Pulumi configuration file for project metadata and tags
- Add instructions to README.md for listing all available Azure locations
- Initialize Go module with Pulumi and Azure SDK dependencies
- Create main.go with Pulumi program to set up an Azure Resource Group and Storage Account, and export the primary storage key

Signed-off-by: Bo-Yi Wu <appleboy.tw@gmail.com>

Release notes

Sourced from github.com/pulumi/pulumi-aws/sdk/v6's releases.

v6.61.0

Does the PR have any schema changes?

Looking good! No breaking changes found.

New resources:

  • rds/instanceDesiredState.InstanceDesiredState

What's Changed

  • Upstream v5.77.0 by @â€‹t0yv0 in pulumi/pulumi-aws#4828

Updates `github.com/pulumi/pulumi/sdk/v3` from 3.141.0 to 3.142.0
Release notes

Sourced from github.com/pulumi/pulumi/sdk/v3's releases.

v3.142.0

3.142.0 (2024-11-26)

Features

  • [cli] Reduce binary size by stripping debug information #17868

  • [sdk/go] Add OutputWithDependencies #17856

  • [sdk/java] Bump pulumi-java to 0.18.0

Bug Fixes

  • [cli] Fix login --interactive when no accounts are in the credentials file #17860

  • [cli/new] Fix new to work with local template directories again #17866

  • [sdkgen/dotnet] Fix parameterized packages to have version.txt #17851

  • [sdk/python] uv toolchain: preserve env-vars when executing uv command #17849

Changelog

Sourced from github.com/pulumi/pulumi/sdk/v3's changelog.

Changelog

Commits
  • 1837a70 Prepare v3.142.0 release (#17870)
  • 350cbf1 Bump pulumi-java to 0.18.0 (#17871)
  • 705a2ae Revert "allow URLs without template for downloading git repos (#17824)" (#17866)
  • faeaace Reduce binary size by stripping debug information (#17868)
  • 7724f9c Fix login --interactive when no accounts are in the credentials file (#17860)
  • 79ee5ac Add some examples and caveats for the Go SDK (#17865)
  • bdf68ba Add OutputWithDependencies (#17856)
  • bb9a80d Enable unsubscriptable-object rule for Python (#17843)
  • 04174f5 Fix parameterised dotnet packages to have version.txt (#17851)
  • 92eb4d4 Enable unused-import rule for Python (#17842)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

commit.message:
feat(Justfile): add pulumi-state as a dependency for deploy-backend

refactor(Justfile): enhance deploy-backend command to include additional pulumi and Kubernetes configurations
The inclusion of `pulumi-state` in the `deploy-backend` recipe ensures
that the deployment process is aware of the state management system,
which is crucial for infrastructure as code (IaC) practices.
Additionally, the deployment command is now configured to explicitly
include credentials and Kubernetes configuration files.

Update first-party Pulumi dependencies (#173)

#### âš ï¸ Breaking change âš ï¸

You must now pass T as the first parameter for any method which does
asserts internally, as is the pattern in Go.

You can fix pretty much all usages using the following batch of `gofmt`
commands:

```bash
gofmt -r 'a.Convert(b) -> a.Convert(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.CopyTo(b) -> a.CopyTo(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.CopyToTempDir() -> a.CopyToTempDir(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Destroy() -> a.Destroy(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.ExportStack() -> a.ExportStack(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.GrpcLog() -> a.GrpcLog(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.ClearGrpcLog() -> a.ClearGrpcLog(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b, c, d, e, f, g) -> a.Import(t, b, c, d, e, f, g)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b, c, d, e, f) -> a.Import(t, b, c, d, e, f)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b, c, d, e) -> a.Import(t, b, c, d, e)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b, c, d) -> a.Import(t, b, c, d)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b, c) -> a.Import(t, b, c)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Import(b) -> a.Import(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.ImportStack(b) -> a.ImportStack(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Install() -> a.Install(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.InstallStack(b) -> a.InstallStack(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Preview() -> a.Preview(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Refresh() -> a.Refresh(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.SetConfig(b, c) -> a.SetConfig(t, b, c)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Up() -> a.Up(t)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.UpdateSource(b) -> a.UpdateSource(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.NewStack(b) -> a.NewStack(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
gofmt -r 'a.Run(b) -> a.Run(t, b)' -w ./**/*_test.go
```

###
[`v3.0.0`](https://redirect.github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/releases/tag/v3.0.0)

[Compare
Source](https://redirect.github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/compare/v2.8.1...v3.0.0)

This is the 3.0.0 major release (see
[#​1425](https://redirect.github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/issues/1425)).

This release delivers significant improvements in flexibility, security
and introduces new features to enhance your Kubernetes experience on
AWS.
AWS recently announced the deprecation of two features used by default
in Pulumi EKS: the aws-auth ConfigMap and the AL2 operating system.
Pulumi EKS v3 addresses these deprecations, enhances the maintainability
of the provider, and aligns it with EKS best practices.

#### Key Highlights of EKS V3

1. **Support for Amazon Linux 2023 (AL2023) and Bottlerocket Operating
Systems**: Enhanced operating system options for node groups, allowing
you to choose the OS that best fits your workloads and compliance needs.
This addresses the upcoming deprecation of Amazon Linux 2 (AL2).

2. **Access Entries for IAM Integration**: Enables replacement of the
deprecated aws-auth ConfigMap with Access Entries for managing
Kubernetes authentication.

3. **EKS Managed Addons**: Simplified management of `vpc-cni`,
`coredns`, and `kube-proxy` as EKS managed addons.

4. **EKS Security Groups for Pods and Network Policies**: Enhanced
network security and control within EKS clusters.

#### New Features and Improvements

##### Support for Amazon Linux 2023 and Bottlerocket

We have expanded the operating system options for node groups in EKS v3
to address the upcoming deprecation of Amazon Linux 2 (AL2). You can now
choose between Amazon Linux 2 (deprecated), Amazon Linux 2023 and
Bottlerocket for your EKS nodes. This flexibility allows you to select
the OS that best fits your workloads, security requirements, and
compliance needs, while ensuring you are using a supported and actively
maintained operating system. We've introduced a new `operatingSystem`
property for node groups to facilitate this choice.

##### Access Entries for IAM Integration

AWS has introduced [Access
Entries](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/eks/latest/userguide/access-entries.html)
as a new method for granting IAM principals access to Kubernetes
resources. This approach relies solely on AWS resources for managing
Kubernetes auth, replacing the deprecated `aws-auth` ConfigMap. You can
now leverage Access Entries by setting the `authenticationMode` to `API`
in your cluster configuration.

##### EKS Managed Addons

The EKS cluster components `vpc-cni`, `coredns`, and `kube-proxy` are
now configured as EKS managed addons. This change simplifies management,
especially for clusters with private API endpoints, and ensures that
these critical components stay up to date automatically. Additionally it
removes the dependency on `kubectl`, allowing pulumi-native management
of clusters.

##### Cluster Autoscaler Integration

Pulumi EKS v3 introduces better support for the Kubernetes Cluster
Autoscaler. A new `ignoreScalingChanges` parameter for node groups
allows Pulumi to ignore external scaling changes, facilitating seamless
integration with dynamic scaling solutions.

##### EKS Security Groups for Pods and Network Policies

We've added support for EKS security groups for pods
([example](https://redirect.github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/tree/master/examples/pod-security-groups))
and EKS Network Policies
([example](https://redirect.github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/tree/master/examples/network-policies)),
providing more granular control over pod-to-pod and pod-to-external
network communication within your EKS clusters.

#### Migration Guide

To help you transition smoothly, we've prepared a migration guide with
these key steps:

1. Update node groups to use AL2023 or explicitly configure AL2 if
needed.
2.  Replace the deprecated `NodeGroup` component with `NodeGroupV2`.
3.  Update your code to handle new output types for certain properties.
4. Review and update your use of default security groups, which can now
be disabled.

Please refer to our [EKS v3 Migration
Documentation](https://www.pulumi.com/registry/packages/eks/how-to-guides/v3-migration/)
for a detailed guide.

**Full Changelog**:
https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi-eks/compare/v2.8.1...v3.0.0

</details>

repository.description: Infrastructure, containers, and serverless apps to AWS, Azure, GCP, and Kubernetes... all deployed with Pulumi

commit.message:
docs(conventions): Add project conventions and guidelines

This commit introduces a CONVENTIONS.md file to establish and document
consistent project guidelines for structuring Node.js-based IaC with
Pulumi on GCP. The document encompasses best practices for module
organization, resource naming conventions, and configuration
management.

- Emphasizes modular architecture for managing GCP resources
- Details technology stack and core dependencies
- Provides development guidelines and naming conventions
- Outlines code style and configuration management practices
- Establishes groundwork for future testing conventions

Additionally, a .aider.conf.yml file is introduced for aiding code
conventions adherence, and a corresponding entry is updated in
.gitignore to ensure proper version control management.

commit.message:
feat(rbac): Implement Kubernetes RBAC and IAM integrations

Enhance access control by introducing RBAC roles and bindings in the
Kubernetes setup. This change also integrates IAM bindings for Google
Cloud Platform (GCP) to grant RBAC users appropriate roles. The newly
created roles - developer, admin, and viewer - ensure that users have
permissions aligned with their responsibilities. This addition improves
resource management and security by providing more granular access
control within the Kubernetes cluster.

- Added RBAC configuration in Pulumi.dev.yaml for users
- Introduced RBAC role definitions and bindings in src/rbac
- Added IAM role binding utility in src/iam
- Updated index.js to include new RBAC and IAM logic
- Dependency on @pulumi/kubernetes added to package.json and updated
  pnpm-lock.yaml to include this change

commit.message:
Upgrade golangci-lint-action to latest v6 (#914)

Motivated by a failure of the [lint step of the pulumi-azure
build](https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi-azure/actions/runs/8980005852/job/24662960390?pr=2007).
> level=error msg=â€œRunning error: canâ€™t run linter
goanalysis_metalinter\nbuildir: failed to load package integration:
could not load export data: no export data for
\â€œ[github.com/pulumi/pulumi/pkg/v3/testing/integration](http://github.com/pulumi/pulumi/pkg/v3/testing/integration)\â€œâ€

This error message can have several causes. One of them is issues with
the Go module cache. golangci/golangci-lint-action and actions/setup-go
compete in their default settings for which one is going to be
installing the dependencies, potentially causing a "cache race".

However, [v5 of
golangci-lint-action](https://github.com/golangci/golangci-lint-action/releases)
has
> feat: remove Go cache management

in the changelog. So, let's try to upgrade.

commit.message:
WIP on a wireguard client (#3019)

* Generate wireguard client api

* WIP on nonsense

* The other stuff I missed because I was in the wrong directory

* More reconciling stuff and tests

* Owner reference

* Sec stuff

* Labels

* Finalizers

* More finalizers

* Client config refs

* Updated CRD and tests for WireguardClient

Added 'configs' to the required fields in the Custom Resource Definition (CRD) for WireguardClient. Updated corresponding unit tests to include this new field. Also, added a ConfigMap volume to the deployment spec and mounted it in the container at '/config/client.conf'.

* Refactored WireguardClientConfig and related functions

Removed 'Value' field from WireguardClientConfig struct, updated corresponding deepcopy function, and adjusted CRD schema. Replaced util.BoolPtr with k8s.io/utils/ptr in app_controller_test.go. Added volume creation logic to wireguardclient_controller.go for handling configs, along with associated volume mounts. Moved PodSecurityContext within PodSpec in CreateDeployment function.

* WIP

* Updated Pulumi version and .NET target framework

The Pulumi version has been updated from 3.135.0 to 3.142.0, and the .NET target framework has been upgraded from net8.0 to net9.0 in the operator project file.

Additionally, the versions of several package references including 'Pulumi', 'Pulumi.FSharp', and 'Pulumi.Kubernetes' have also been updated in the same project file.

Lastly, the SDK version in global.json has been incremented from 9.0.100 to 9.0.101.

* Refactored solution structure

Significant changes have been made to the solution structure. Several projects and their corresponding configurations have been removed, resulting in a cleaner and more manageable solution file. This should improve navigation and maintainability of the codebase.

* Updated Kustomization configuration

The kustomization.yaml file has been updated to include new image details. The changes include the addition of apiVersion, kind, and images fields. The images field now specifies a new controller image with its name, newName, and newTag properties.

* Refactor Kubernetes deployment in F# code

Significant changes have been made to the Kubernetes deployment process in the F# program. The previous implementation using Helm charts has been replaced with a Kustomize-based approach. This simplifies the infrastructure setup by removing unnecessary dependencies and streamlining resource management. The namespace retrieval has also been removed, as it's no longer needed with this new approach.

commit.message:
Fix shims (#2511)

## Problem
When running `go list -m` in a provider upgraded to use bridge v3.93.1
you will get this error:

```
go: github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls@v0.0.0: invalid version: unknown revision v0.0.0
go: github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls/shim@v0.0.0-00010101000000-000000000000: invalid version: unknown revision 000000000000
go: github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-random/randomshim@v0.0.0-00010101000000-000000000000: invalid version: unknown revision 000000000000
```

Ian called this out in
https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi-terraform-bridge/pull/2473#discussion_r1799354257.
My response there is true in the sense that providers _do still build_
just fine -- `go build`, `go test` etc. don't touch these unused
modules. The caveat I overlooked is that some IDE integrations (or more
specifically any tooling built around `go list`) _will_ try to resolve
all of these direct and indirect dependencies.

When we consolidated modules, we moved `replace` directives for these
shims out of the test module and into the root module.

## Option 0: Bring back all the modules

I beg you not to do this but I do want to call it out as an option if
the team would prefer it. I outline two more "idiomatic" options below.

## Option 1: Handle replacements in the consumer

As a reminder, the `replace` directive only applies to the module where
it's defined -- primarily to keep Go's minimal version selection
algorithm simple and fast, but also to give downstream modules complete
control of their builds. Hence `replace` is best suited for temporary
overrides, for example to point at a local branch.

Permanent `replace` directives do happen and we use them quite a lot,
though. If a module truly needs a permanent `replace` to work properly
(which, to be clear, should be avoided!), its consumers need to mirror
the same `replace`.

In other words, Option 1 is to not make any changes. Downstream projects
can resolve this issue by copying these lines into `go.mod`:

```
replace github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls/shim => github.com/pulumi/pulumi-terraform-bridge/v3/pkg/pf/tests/internal/tlsshim v0.0.0-20241025174446-f865647b85ed

replace github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls => github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls v1.2.1-0.20210201152640-49d7590ccf3f

replace github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-random/randomshim => github.com/pulumi/pulumi-terraform-bridge/v3/pkg/pf/tests/internal/randomshim v0.0.0-20241025174446-f865647b85ed
```

Clearly this is burdensome. For a real-world data point, this is the
same strategy adopted by the k8s ecosystem and it has made dependency
management with k8s notoriously painful.

We should not do this.

## Option 2: Fork instead of abusing modules

`tlsshim` and `randomshim` are their own modules because they
intentionally trick the compiler into exposing internal terraform
packages. This `internal` import is only legal if your module is
identified as
`github.com/terraform-providers/terraform-provider-random`:


https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi-terraform-bridge/blob/7dfbcd601c7392fbf04bdec4c83a56b1ef115bc6/pkg/pf/tests/internal/randomshim/shim.go#L17-L24

This is hacky but it matches the guidance we gives to users, and it is
_workable_ as long as the module consuming these shims doesn't have
downstream consumers of its own. This is the case with most providers,
but tfbridge is different because it _is_ meant to be consumed as a
library.

A more typical remedy for consuming private types is to fork the
dependency and expose what you need. We could fork these two
repositories under the `pulumi` org, but new repos come with their own
overhead.

Instead, I opted to simply check-in the upstream random and tls
providers. I preserved the commits we were previously pinned to
([c6e90de46687](https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-random/commit/c6e90de466877b3b0d6dd39c7573c1cfedf0a58d)
and
[afdd54107aba](https://github.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-tls/commit/afdd54107aba371f7e030b2d935cceb1a6050fe9),
respectively) so licensing is unaffected.

This way our `go.mod` will reflect a dependency on a public module that
is still consumable downstream (e.g. `terraform-provider-random`), and
we will use forks that expose the internals when testing.

This PR implements Option 2.

commit.message:
Actually operating on the operator (#2899)

* Updated AppSpec and kubebuilder script

In the operator API, removed scaffolding comments and replaced 'Foo' field with 'Repository' in AppSpec. In the kubebuilder script, added a prompt for user input of 'Group', replacing hardcoded value.

* Go crap

* Updated Makefile for better project management

The Makefile has been updated to improve the build process and project management. A new 'manifests' target has been added to generate controller and operator manifests. The 'tidy' target now includes a step to tidy up the Go modules in the operator directory. This will help keep our dependencies clean and up-to-date, ensuring smoother builds and less clutter in our codebase.

* Fleshing out the App resource

* Updated scaffolding options in AppSpec

Enhanced the 'scaffold' field in the AppSpec struct to support two types of scaffolding: "typescript" and "helm". The default option is "typescript", which performs scaffolding for TypeScript. The new option, "helm", creates an empty helm chart in the app path. These changes are reflected in both the Go code and YAML configuration file.

* Implementing the thing

* Added new rule to .gitignore

A new ignore rule has been added to the .gitignore file. This will prevent end-to-end test folders from being tracked by Git, improving repository cleanliness and reducing unnecessary files in version control.

* Updated 'Manage' field to pointer type and added management logic

The 'Manage' field in the AppSpec struct has been updated from a boolean to a pointer to a boolean. This allows for three states: true, false, and nil. The management logic in the app controller has been updated accordingly. If 'Manage' is set to nil or true, the app is managed by default. If it's set to false, the app is not managed. A utility function for creating a bool pointer was also added. Tests have been updated and expanded to cover these changes.

* App conditions

* Added Pulumi stack initialization status

Introduced a new field to track the initialization status of an App's Pulumi stack. This is represented as a condition in the App's status, which is set to false by default indicating that the stack has not been initialized yet. Corresponding tests have also been added to verify this behavior.

* Enabled E2E tests in CI workflow

The End-to-End (E2E) tests that were previously commented out have been enabled again in the continuous integration (CI) workflow. This change will ensure a more comprehensive testing process before deployment.

commit.message:
None of this is right but I need to tie off the branch (#2769)

* Housecleaning

* The login keys and stuff

Updated dependencies in package.json

The versions of several dependencies have been updated to their latest versions. Additionally, the 'fp-ts' dependency has been added.

Refactored cluster provisioning logic

The code changes involve a significant refactor of the cluster provisioning logic. The previous implementation has been replaced with a more functional approach, using fp-ts library for better composability and type safety. A new ClusterNode class was introduced to encapsulate node-related operations. This class includes methods for checking control plane and worker ports. The provision function now handles different types of nodes (controlplane or worker) differently based on their tag. The overall structure of the code is now more modular and easier to maintain.

Updated cluster configuration

Removed the 'wipe' option from two nodes in the production cluster configuration. This change will prevent automatic disk wiping on these nodes, preserving existing data during future updates or maintenance tasks.

Refactor node configuration with zod schema

The Node interface has been refactored to use a zod schema, which provides more robust type checking. A new Vlan object and an AnyPrimitive union have been introduced for better flexibility in defining node properties. The getNodes function has also been added to parse the nodes from the configuration. This change enhances code maintainability and readability by providing a clear structure for Node objects.

Added tag and name to Vlan object

The Vlan object in the configuration file has been updated with two new properties: 'tag' and 'name'. The 'tag' property is a number, while the 'name' property is a string. This enhancement provides more detailed information for each Vlan instance.

Added VLAN configuration to cluster nodes

The update includes the addition of VLAN configurations for each node in the cluster. This new setup specifies the tag, name, and interface for each VLAN. The changes aim to improve network segmentation and security within the cluster environment.

Updated ClusterNode class with VLAN configuration

Significant changes include:
- Imported YAML and additional types from '@pulumi/command'
- Added a new 'connection' property in the ClusterNode class
- Refactored the 'run' method to use the new 'connection' property
- Introduced a new method, 'configureVlan', for setting up VLAN configurations
- Updated the provision function to call 'configureVlan' if a node has a VLAN defined. The previous switch-case logic is commented out for now.

Added new dependency in package.json

A new dependency '@unmango/pulumi-kubernetes-the-hard-way' version '^0.0.30' has been added to the package.json file of the pinkdiamond cluster. This update is part of ongoing efforts to enhance our Kubernetes infrastructure management capabilities.

Updated cluster configuration

Added new versions for containerd and runc in the cluster configuration. This update ensures that we are using the latest stable releases of these dependencies, improving overall system stability and performance.

Refactor config object and type definitions

Significant changes include:
- Replaced `TheClusterTls` object with `Versions` object in the configuration
- Moved `TheClusterTls` definition to a later part of the code
- Changed `Versions` from an interface to a type, inferred from the new `Versions` zod schema
- Added parsing of 'versions' from the configuration into the exported `versions` constant.

WIP on pd-again
Add CNI plugins version and node architecture

Extended the configuration schema to include a new field for CNI plugins version in the Versions object. Also added an architecture field to the Node object, which can be either 'amd64' or 'arm64'.

Updated dependency version

The version of a key dependency has been updated to the latest one. This update is expected to bring in new features and improvements from the upstream project, enhancing overall functionality and performance.

Updated containerd and added cniPlugins versions

The version of containerd has been updated to 1.7.19 from 1.4.4 in the Pulumi configuration file for better compatibility and performance improvements. Additionally, a new entry for cniPlugins with version 1.5.1 has been added to the same configuration file to support enhanced networking features.

Refactor port configuration and add worker tools installation

Significant changes include:
- Refactored the checkPort method into a more general configurePort method that handles both creation and deletion of firewall rules.
- Added methods to enable IPv4 packet forwarding and install necessary tools on worker nodes.
- Uncommented code in provision function to call new methods based on node type.

Updated worker tools installation process

Significant changes have been made to the worker tools installation process. The 'interpolate' function and 'Wget' class from '@pulumi/pulumi' and '@unmango/pulumi-commandx/remote' respectively, have been imported. A new instance of 'ContainerdInstall' has been created with additional parameters. Furthermore, a new instance of 'Wget', named 'containerdSystemd', has been added to fetch containerd service configuration from a remote URL. Lastly, a new command for starting containerd service has also been introduced which depends on both the containerd installation and its systemd configuration.

Add containerd config

* Add new hosts project

Updated dependencies and added license in package.json

The package.json file for the 'thecluster-hosts' project has been updated. The changes include:
- Addition of a license field
- Update to the versions of existing dependencies
- Introduction of new dependencies
- Reordering of devDependencies and dependencies sections

Updated dependencies in package.json

Added 'zod' to the list of dependencies in the package.json file. This new addition will provide additional functionality for our project. No other changes were made to existing dependencies or devDependencies.

Introduced ControlPlaneNode and WorkerNode classes

Added two new classes, ControlPlaneNode and WorkerNode, which extend the base Node class. These classes are part of a larger infrastructure update to better manage nodes within the system. The changes also include exporting these new classes for external use.

Added infrastructure host configuration

Introduced a new TypeScript file for managing the infrastructure hosts' configuration. This includes defining schemas for Node, Vlan, and Versions using zod library. Also added functions to parse these configurations from the Pulumi stack's config. The parsed configurations are exported as 'controlplanes', 'workers', and 'versions'.

Added fp-ts dependency

The package.json file in the infra/hosts directory has been updated to include a new dependency, fp-ts version 2.16.7. This addition will provide functional programming utilities for TypeScript projects within our infrastructure hosts.

Refactor node classes to extend NodeArgs

The ControlPlaneNodeArgs and WorkerNodeArgs interfaces now extend the NodeArgs interface. The Node class has been updated to include a config property, which is initialized from the passed arguments. This change simplifies the code structure and improves reusability of common properties across different node types.

Updated versions in Pulumi config

Added new version configurations for various components such as containerd, k8s, ksca, talos, runc, crictl and cniPlugins in the Pulumi configuration file. This will ensure that these components are using the specified versions during deployment.

Added new node export

A new node has been exported in the components index. This will allow for more flexible usage of nodes within the infrastructure.

Updated tsconfig.json file

The tsconfig.json file has been updated to include additional files in the "files" array. This change will ensure that these new files are included during the TypeScript compilation process.

Added new production configuration file

A new YAML configuration file has been added for the production environment. This includes details for control planes and workers such as hostname, architecture, IP addresses, cluster IPs, installation disks, and VLAN configurations. Some nodes also have specific labels assigned to them. A few potential configurations are commented out for possible future use.

Refactor host configuration in infra

The infrastructure hosts have been refactored to improve the organization and readability of the code. The changes include:
- Replacing a single import with specific component imports for better clarity.
- Creating an array of nodes using map functions, which simplifies the creation process.
- Using reduce function to generate outputs from nodes, making it more efficient.
- Exporting individual hosts and hostnames for easier access elsewhere in the code.

Added yaml dependency to package.json

The package.json file has been updated with a new dependency. The 'yaml' library, version 2.4.5, has been added to the list of dependencies in the project's infrastructure hosts configuration. This addition will allow for better handling and parsing of YAML files within the project.

Updated production infrastructure configuration

Added VLAN configuration to the host in the production environment. The new settings include a VLAN tag, name, and interface. This will help in network segmentation and improve security by isolating network traffic.

Added VLAN configuration functionality

A new class, Vlan, has been introduced to handle VLAN configurations. This includes creating and removing netplan configurations, setting file permissions, and applying the netplan. The YAML module is used to generate the configuration content. Significant changes include:
- Creation of a new Vlan class extending CommandComponent
- Implementation of methods for managing netplan (removal, creation, permission setting)
- Use of YAML for generating network configuration content
- Registration of outputs for tracking state

Introduced CommandComponent in infra

This commit introduces a new abstract class, CommandComponent, in the infrastructure layer. This class includes methods for running commands and teeing outputs with connection details. It also defines types and interfaces related to command execution such as RunArgs, RunOpts, and CommandComponentArgs. The constructor of this class sets up the configuration and connection details required for executing commands.

Updated tsconfig.json with new components

Two new components, command.ts and vlan.ts, have been added to the tsconfig.json file. This update ensures these files are included in the TypeScript compilation process.

Added new dependency to package.json

A new dependency '@pulumi/tls' version '^5.0.4' has been added to the project's package.json file. This update is part of ongoing efforts to enhance infrastructure management capabilities within the application.

Refactor command component and add new methods

The CommandComponent class has been refactored to improve its flexibility. The connection property is now obtained through a new abstract method, getConnection(), instead of being directly assigned in the constructor. This change allows subclasses to provide their own implementation for establishing connections.

Additionally, several new methods have been added: chmod(), wget(), and mkdir(). These methods create instances of Chmod, Wget, and Mkdir respectively, providing more functionality to the CommandComponent class.

Lastly, some imports were updated to reflect these changes.

Refactor Node class and add new features

Significant changes have been made to the Node class. The base class has been changed from ComponentResource to CommandComponent. New properties, loginKey and vlan, have been added. The constructor now initializes these properties and handles their configuration if provided in the arguments. A method for establishing a connection using the host name and private key has also been introduced. Additionally, a method for allowing ports through firewall rules has been implemented.

Enhanced control plane and worker nodes, updated VLAN

Significant changes include:
- Enhanced the ControlPlaneNode class to allow specific ports on both localhost and clusterIp.
- Updated Vlan class to handle connection arguments more efficiently.
- Expanded WorkerNode class with methods for IPv4 packet forwarding, containerd installation, and tool installations.

Added new configuration for containerd

A comprehensive configuration file for containerd has been added. This includes settings for plugins, gRPC, metrics, and various other parameters. The changes aim to provide a more robust and customizable setup for managing containers.

Refactor CommandComponent class in command.ts

The CommandComponent class has been significantly refactored. The changes include:
- Removal of specific methods like 'run', 'tee', 'chmod', 'wget' and 'mkdir'.
- Addition of a generic method named 'exec' to replace the removed methods.
- Changes in type definitions for better flexibility and readability.
- Simplification of constructor logic by removing unnecessary conditionals.
- Replacing the config property with a connection property, which is more relevant to the class's purpose.

Added new components to infrastructure

Several new components have been added to the infrastructure. These include CNI plugins, Containerd, Crictl, IPv4 packet forwarding and Runc. Each of these components has its own TypeScript file defining its structure and functionality. The tsconfig.json file has also been updated to include these new files in the project build process.

Refactored code for better modularity and readability

The changes include:
- Refactoring of the Node, Vlan, and WorkerNode classes to improve code organization.
- Removal of redundant methods and properties.
- Simplification of the way commands are executed in the Node and Vlan classes.
- Separation of concerns in the WorkerNode class by moving some functionality into separate classes (Ipv4PacketForwarding, Containerd, CniPlugins).
- Changes to import statements to reflect these modifications.

Refactor node provisioning in infra

The infrastructure code has been refactored to streamline the process of provisioning nodes. A new function, 'provision', has been introduced which takes a constructor and returns a function that can be used to create new instances of ControlPlaneNode or WorkerNode. This change simplifies the creation of these nodes by abstracting away some of the details and reducing code duplication. The use of this new function is demonstrated in the updated way controlplanes and workers are mapped when creating an array of nodes.

Added script to write public keys

A new bash script has been added that writes public keys. The script checks for the presence of STACK_PATH and exits if it's not found. It then uses git, pulumi, and jq commands to generate a JSON output of hostKeys which is saved in a .config/out.json file.

Updated import and connection handling

The import statement in the command.ts file has been updated to include 'Output' and 'output'. The type of 'connection' in CommandComponentArgs interface and CommandComponent class has been changed from inputs.ConnectionArgs to Output<inputs.ConnectionArgs>. Also, the assignment of this.connection now uses output() function.

Updated host configuration and key management

The host configuration has been significantly updated. New imports have been added, including Output and StackReference from '@pulumi/pulumi' and PrivateKey from '@pulumi/tls'. The HostKeys object now includes several new keys.

The Node object's hostname property has been changed to use the keys of HostKeys instead of a string. A new Hosts object has also been introduced, which maps each key in HostKeys to a Node.

Two new types, HostKeys and Hosts, have been exported. The getNodes function has been removed, replaced by directly requiring the hosts from the config using the newly defined Hosts zod schema.

A StackReference 'pki' was created with name 'UnstoppableMango/pki/prod', which is used to require output for hostKeys. This change improves how we manage private keys across different hosts in our infrastructure setup.

Added new hosts to production infrastructure

The production infrastructure configuration has been updated with the addition of several new hosts. These include both arm64 and amd64 architecture machines, each with their own unique hostname, IP address, cluster IP, and installation disk. Some of these hosts also have VLAN configurations and node labels specified.

Refactor node provisioning and configuration

The code changes involve a significant refactor of the node provisioning process. The 'provision' function has been updated to take an additional argument for the private key, which is now passed directly instead of being generated within the function. This change allows for more flexibility in managing keys.

Additionally, the way nodes are created and stored has been altered. Instead of mapping over arrays of configurations, specific nodes are now provisioned individually with their respective host and key data. This approach provides clearer visibility into each node's creation.

Lastly, the method for exporting hostnames has been adjusted to work with the new structure by extracting values from the 'nodes' object.

Updated host connection parameter

The host connection parameter in the provision function has been updated. Previously, it was set to use the hostname for establishing a connection. Now, it uses the IP address instead. This change should improve the reliability of connections in environments where DNS resolution might be problematic.

Updated container directory creation

Modified the code to ensure parent directories are created when setting up the containerd configuration. This prevents potential issues if parent directories don't exist beforehand.

Refactored node provisioning and dependencies

The node provisioning function has been updated to include an optional dependency parameter. This allows for the creation of dependent resources in a more controlled manner. Additionally, nodes have been separated into control planes and workers for better organization and clarity.

Updated CNI plugins and worker node components

Enhanced the CNI plugins component by adding a directory output and implementing a new Mkdir command. The worker node component now includes a reference to the updated CNI plugins. Also, added a TODO comment in the Vlan class for future debugging. Removed an unnecessary import from the config file.

Renamed config.toml to default_config.toml

The configuration file in the containerd directory has been renamed from 'config.toml' to 'default_config.toml'. This change is intended to clarify its role as the default configuration.

Added containerd configuration and patching script

A new configuration file for containerd has been added, along with a patch file to modify specific settings. A bash script has also been introduced to automate the process of applying this patch to the base configuration.

Added Makefile for containerd configuration

This commit introduces a new Makefile in the infra/hosts directory. The Makefile exports two environment variables, WORKING_DIR and PROJECT_DIR, and includes a target for patching the containerd configuration file using a script located in the hack directory.

Refactor containerd component for clarity

Significant changes include:
- Renamed variables to more generic names for better readability
- Extracted systemd directory path into a constant
- Added an execution command to apply configuration changes immediately after they are made. This ensures that the system is always running with the latest configurations.

Added default config generation for containerd

The Makefile has been updated to include a new target that generates the default configuration for containerd. This change will help in setting up containerd with its default settings, making it easier to get started or reset configurations if needed.

Fix the type weirdness

Added Kubelet component and integrated it with WorkerNode

In this update, a new Kubelet component was created and added to the infrastructure. This component is now part of the WorkerNode class, alongside existing components like Ipv4PacketForwarding, Containerd, and CniPlugins. The architecture argument for these components has been refactored into a single object for cleaner code. Also updated tsconfig.json to include the new Kubelet file.

Updated dependency version

The version of the "@unmango/pulumi-kubernetes-the-hard-way" dependency has been updated from "^0.0.31" to "^0.0.32". This update ensures we are using the latest features and improvements from this package in our project.

Added Kubernetes Node Agent service

Created a new systemd service for the Kubernetes Node Agent (kubelet). The service is configured to start after the network is online and will always restart on failure. Also, a patch file was created to modify the kubelet execution path in the service configuration. A default version of this service was also added with a different execution path for kubelet.

Enhanced Makefile with Kubernetes versioning

The Makefile has been updated to include Kubernetes versioning. It now fetches the Kubernetes release URL and version from Pulumi configuration. The process of patching the containerd config file has also been modified, it now uses a diff between default and current configurations. Additionally, kubelet service files have been added with a mechanism to generate patches based on differences between default and current service files.

Added Kubectl component and integrated it with Node

In this update, a new Kubectl component has been added to the infrastructure. This component is now also integrated into the Node class. The architecture argument for the Kubectl installation is passed from the Node configuration. Additionally, references to kubectl have been included in relevant files.

Updated infrastructure configuration

Added a new version of krel to the Pulumi.yaml configuration file. This update ensures our infrastructure is using the latest tools for better performance and stability.

Updated dependency version

The version of the "@unmango/pulumi-kubernetes-the-hard-way" dependency has been updated from "^0.0.32" to "^0.0.33". This update is part of routine maintenance to keep dependencies up-to-date and ensure compatibility with other packages in use.

Clean up scripts

Phony kubelet target

Clean up config

Add a common default k8s version

Added asset and remote imports in kubelet.ts

The code changes include the addition of 'asset' and 'remote' from '@pulumi/pulumi'. The 'Defaults' import was also added from '../config'. A new constant, systemdDirectory, was defined using Defaults.systemdDirectory. Additionally, a new config constant was created to execute the CopyToRemote command with specified parameters.

Added Kubeadm component and updated tsconfig

A new Kubeadm component has been added to the infrastructure hosts. This includes defining a new interface for KubeadmArgs and a class for Kubeadm that extends CommandComponent. The tsconfig.json file has also been updated to include this new component.

Added kubeadm support in Makefile

The Makefile has been updated to include support for kubeadm. This includes the creation of a new patch file and configuration file for kubeadm, as well as changes to the existing kubelet and containerd sections. The new files are fetched from a specified URL and then modified according to our needs.

Added Kubeadm configuration and systemd service setup

The update includes the addition of Kubeadm configuration in the infrastructure hosts. The changes also include setting up a systemd service for kubelet, which is now enabled on startup. Furthermore, the Kubeadm component has been added to the Node class.

Updated deletion command in CNI plugins

The deletion command in the CNI plugins component has been updated to use a variable for the directory path instead of a hardcoded string. This change improves flexibility and maintainability of the code.

Added chmod execution and Runc component

In this update, we've added the execution of 'chmod' to change file permissions in kubeadm, kubectl, and kubelet components. This ensures that the installed files have executable permissions. Additionally, a new component 'Runc' has been introduced to the WorkerNode class.

Added new Kubernetes configuration files

A new configuration file for Kubernetes has been added. This includes the ClusterConfiguration and KubeletConfiguration with their respective apiVersions. The kubernetesVersion is set to v1.30.2 and cgroupDriver is set to systemd in the KubeletConfiguration.

Added network bonding support

A new class 'Bonding' has been introduced to handle network interface bonding. This class extends the CommandComponent and uses the Pulumi library for infrastructure as code. It includes methods to copy configuration to remote hosts and execute commands related to modprobe on these hosts. The tsconfig.json file has also been updated to include this new component.

* Enhanced network bonding functionality

The code changes introduce an enhancement to the network bonding functionality. The Bonding class now accepts a new argument 'bond' which is used to configure the bond interfaces, addresses, and parameters. YAML is used to stringify these configurations. Additionally, a new Bond object has been defined in the config file with properties like name, interfaces, addresses, and mode. This allows for more flexible and detailed configuration of network bonds.

* Updated production infrastructure configuration

Added VLAN configurations to the production infrastructure. Two nodes now have additional settings for VLAN, including tag, name, and interface details. This update enhances network segmentation and improves security by isolating network traffic.

* Refactor node provisioning and export logic

Significant changes include:
- Extended the `NewNode` type to accept a generic that extends from `Node`
- Introduced a new type, `CreateNode`, for the provision function return type
- Refactored the provision function to use these new types
- Replaced direct node exports with calls to a new function, `toExport`, which returns an object containing key node properties
- Added placeholder code for handling specific node types within the `toExport` function

* WIP on pd-again
Added Netplan component to infrastructure

A new Netplan component has been added to the infrastructure. This includes the creation of a new file, netplan.ts, and its addition to tsconfig.json. The Netplan class extends CommandComponent and provides methods for removing, configuring, applying changes, and managing permissions related to netplan configurations.

* Refactor network configuration handling

Significant changes include:
- Removed `bonding.ts` and `vlan.ts` files, moving their functionality into `netplan.ts`.
- Updated `node.ts` to use the new Netplan class for both bonding and VLAN configurations.
- Added static methods in `netplan.ts` to handle VLAN and bond configurations.
- Adjusted tsconfig.json to reflect file structure changes.

* Updated hostname in production config

The hostname in the production configuration file has been updated. The previous placeholder comment has been replaced with the correct hostname.

* Updated import and delete command

The import statement in the netplan.ts file has been updated to include 'interpolate' from '@pulumi/pulumi'. The delete command syntax has also been modified to use 'interpolate' for better string handling.

* Refactor netplan and node components

The code changes include a refactoring of the 'netplan' and 'node' components. In 'netplan', the object properties have been simplified for better readability. The file deletion command has also been updated to force delete files.

In the 'node' component, an import statement was modified to include 'asset'. Additional functionality was added for handling bonding configurations, including copying to remote, modprobe creation and deletion. Lastly, a minor formatting change was made in the allowPort method for improved readability.

* Added ethernet configuration support

The code changes introduce the ability to configure ethernet settings in the infrastructure. This includes:
- Addition of an 'ethernets' field in the Node configuration
- Modification of Netplan class to handle ethernet configurations
- Adjustments in node.ts to execute Netplan with ethernet configurations if present
- Dependency management between bond and ethernets configurations

* Updated VLAN configuration in production

Added a new VLAN configuration to the production environment. The changes include setting up a new VLAN with tag 69, naming it as enp8s0.69 and associating it with the interface enp8s0.

* Fix netplan config path

* Gettin er back on the ol straight and narrow

* Idk what was going on here but I want it in the git history

* This is all wrong but I want my rantings in the history

commit.message:
Add files via upload

This project implements a simple blog app using vanilla Django function-based views and class-based views as well as DRF function and class-based views. There is also an implementation of the same application using GraphQL. The application involves a simple data model including users, posts with text and image and post likes. Local development using virtual environments and docker are both covered in detail, including guidance on how to run the application on different operating systems (Linux, Intel Mac, M1 Mac, Windows, WSL). There is 100% test coverage for the project and comprehensive e2e tests using Cypress.

Deployment to AWS environment on Elastic Container Service (ECS) is shown with both:

CDK and a CDK construct library that I wrote specifically for deploying containerized Django projects on AWS
Terraform using terraform-aws-django
This project is originally designed as a reference or example project that I can use when I need to recall common patterns, syntax and frequently-used code snippets. I have tried to carefully document each part of the development process as a guide for someone who wants to learn how this project is built and deployed from the ground up. Please visit the project documentation site (briancaffey.github.io/django-step-by-step/) for a complete explanation of the project, step-by-step.

This project is open-source and newcomers to Django and Python and welcome to create issues and pull requests.

Core application
This project implements a simple microblogging application called Î¼blog. Here are some of the core features of Î¼blog:

Anyone (including unauthenticated users) can publish posts with text and an optional image
Users can sign up for accounts that are activated by clicking a link in an email
Signed-in users can like posts
Signed-in users can edit and delete their own posts
Implementation
Î¼blog's core microblogging application is implemented in 5 different ways:

Django function-based views
Django class-based views
Django REST Framework function-based views
Django REST Framework class-based views
GraphQL with Graphene
Each implementation is tested and documented with OpenAPI (Swagger UI). GraphiQL is exposed for the GraphQL API which includes documentation for queries and mutations.

Django templates and Bootstrap are used for the function and class based Django views. Vue.js is used to implement the like button using AJAX (with axios).

Local development
This project is heavily focused on the process of setting up the development environment. This project has been tested and developed on:

Ubuntu 20.04
macOS 11.4 (Apple Silicon)
Windows 10 (WSL + Docker Desktop)
Windows 10 PowerShell development environment is still WIP. Here are some important features of the local development environment:

Makefile
A Makefile is included in the root of the project to document. This file helps to document each step of the local development environment and deployment process.

Python dependencies
This project's Python dependencies are managed with poetry. Poetry dependencies and dev-dependencies are specified in pyproject.toml. These dependencies are exported to two files:

requirements.txt: This contains only the dependencies that are required by the project for running in production
requirements_dev.txt: This contains all the dependencies that are required for running in production and for local development
Developing with virtual environments
The application can be developed with a virtual environment locally. This requires starting postgres and redis services locally. Alternatively, postgres, redis and other supporting services can be started with a docker-compose file that exposes the services on localhost.

Developing with docker
Docker is a popular choice for developing and deploying applications, including Django. docker-compose can be used to run the application and dependent services in containers. See docker-compose.yml in the root directory for more details.

The docker-compose file contains the following services:

postgres: Postgres service
redis: Redis service
pgadmin: Postgres admin service
redis-commander: Redis admin service
backend: main Django web application
celery_worker: celery worker that processes the default queue
celery_beat: celery process that queues tasks on a schedule
mailhog: a local SMTP server for testing
The application can also run locally inside a local Kubernetes cluster. This is made possible with minikube. cdk8s and pulumi are both used to show how kubernetes manifest files can be generated dynamically from code (TypeScript) and deployed to a cluster.

e2e testing with Cypress
Cypress is used for e2e testing which can run locally against the docker-compose development environment. To test user registration and email verification in e2e tests, MailHog and the MailHog API are used to retrieve the email confirmation link from the email sent by the Django application.

Continuous Integration
Multiple tools are used for running unit tests and code quality checks on each commit. These include:

GitHub Actions
GitLab CI
Bitbucket Pipelines
Continuous integration checks that all unit tests pass and that code is formatted correctly. Unit tests run the Python code in a simulated environment that contains the dependent services (postgres and redis). The following tools are used in CI:

flake8
black
pytest
Deployment
This project focuses on deployment to AWS using Elastic Container Service.

AWS ECS
ECS is my preferred way of running containerized web applications on AWS. To help document best practices for deploying Django applications on ECS, I wrote a reusable CDK construct library that handles infrastructure provisioning for typical deployment scenarios. This project can be found here.

The Django ECS construct included in the library creates the following AWS resources:

VPC (public, private and isolated subnets, NAT Gateways, routing tables, Internet Gateway, etc)
S3 bucket for storing static files and media files
ECS Cluster (a grouping of ECS resources)
ECS tasks and services for various components of the application (web, celery workers, management commands and tasks)
A docker image built from our Django application code and specified Dockerfile
Application Load Balancer
TLS certificate that can attached to the Application Load Balancer terminating SSL/TLS
A Route53 DNS record that points to the Application Load Balancer public DNS name
AWS RDS Postgres database instance that servers as the database for the Django application
A single-node AWS ElastiCache Redis cluster that provides caching and messaging brokering for celery workers
Security groups that allow for the stateless application layer to communicate with the Postgres database and Redis cluster
Automated database migrations for the Django application using ECS tasks
The Django ECS construct takes a few inputs, including:

The path to the Django application code
The path to the Dockerfile that defines the main image used for the Django application
The domain name in Route53 that will be used to generate DNS records in your account
Optionally provide the ARN of an ACM certificate to be attached to the Application Load Balancer
A list of strings to be used as the command for the web service
A list of strings to be used as the command for the celery workers
A list of strings to be used as the command for the celery beat process
This project can deploy ECS from the command line (using make cdk-deploy) or from a CI/CD pipeline. GitHub Actions and GitLab CI both include pipeline stages that deploy the application to AWS ECS.

Additional ECS Exec is used to run management commands and open shells inside of the containers running on Fargate.

This project is open source and MIT Licensed
See LICENSE.md

12 Factor App
This project tries to follow the 12 Factor App principles. Here are the 12 factors of the 12 Factor app with a brief description of how they are achieved in this project across multiple deployment environments.

I: Codebase
The code can be found in multiple public repositories:

One codebase tracked in revision control, many deploys

GitHub (please open any issues, pull requests or discussions here): https://github.com/briancaffey/django-step-by-step
II: Dependencies
There are a few different ways in which this project manages dependencies:

poetry manages Python dependencies
npm manages TypeScript/JavaScript dependencies for the construct library application
The Dockerfile defines dependencies needed for the container, including the version of Python to use
The django-cdk library defines specific version of AWS services to use, such as the version of postgres and Redis that are used
terraform-aws-django also defines specific versions, such as the database engine version to use for Postgres
III: Config
There is a good amount of environment variables used for configuration both locally and in the different production environments.

Locally, the application uses default values that allow development in a virtual environment to work without the need for configuring any environment variables as a separate step.

For example, Postgres is configured with the following default values in the Django application:

DATABASES = {
    "default": {
        "ENGINE": "django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2",
        "NAME": os.environ.get("POSTGRES_NAME", "postgres"),
        "USER": os.environ.get("POSTGRES_USERNAME", "postgres"),
        "PASSWORD": os.environ.get("POSTGRES_PASSWORD", "postgres"),
        "HOST": os.environ.get("POSTGRES_SERVICE_HOST", "localhost"),
        "PORT": os.environ.get("POSTGRES_SERVICE_PORT", 5432),
    }
}
The django-cdk application uses environment variables to determine which options to use for deployment. For example, the HostedZoneName is read in from the environment and use to determine which DNS records and ACM records to create. CloudFormation Stacks help to isolate environments, and no infrastructure is shared between environments.

A litmus test for whether an app has all config correctly factored out of the code is whether the codebase could be made open source at any moment, without compromising any credentials.

This is another important point from the 12 Factor App principles that is true for this project.

One interesting part about config is the Postgres password for the ECS environment. The ECS environment uses an AWS Secrets Manager Secret to store the database password information, including the password, in a JSON string.

The name of this Secret is passed as an environment to the Django application, and the Django application uses another library to retrieve and cache the database password for later use. Again, the value of the secret is not passed to Django as an environment variable, but the name of the Secret (from AWS Secrets Manager) is the value passed. This way we don't even have to worry about what the password is. It is not stored in the code base and it is not even stored anywhere in config (until is created in AWS Secrets Manager).

IV: Backing Services
In AWS, it is easy to start relying on AWS services such as RDS, ElastiCache, S3 and other services.

V: Build, release, run
This step in the 12 Factor App is where CDK really shines. The cdk deploy command builds, releases and runs the application in one command. First, it is important to note that CDK uses something called DockerImageAsset, which allows us to point to the directory and Dockerfile of an application that we want to build and push to a docker registry. To use this feature, we must first run cdk bootstrap once in our AWS account. This will create the ECR registry that any DockerImageAsset will be pushed to.

When cdk deploy runs, it first builds and pushes the docker image to the ECR registry created by the cdk bootstrap command. cdk deploy then proceeds to create or update the AWS resources defined in the construct. Another advantage of CDK is automatic rollbacks.

VI: Processes
Execute the app as one or more stateless processes

In each environment, both local and non-local, the application's processes are clearly defined.

The CDK construct is passed a list of strings that define the processes that are run in the container for the wep services as well as the celery worker and celery beat processes.

VII: Port binding
This is done in ECS.

VIII: Concurrency
The array of process types and number of processes of each type is known as the process formation.

The ECS construct has a simple process formation: web service that scales up and down between a minimum and maximum number of instances. Celery workers that scale between a minimum and maximum number of instances, and a single celery beat process.

IX: Disposability
Using CDK is a great way to put application disposability into practice. ECS services make sure that some number of ECS Tasks are running at a given point in time. If we go into the AWS console and delete a task, it will be started again almost instantly.

X: Dev/prod parity
This project makes dev/prod parity somewhat trivial. Using Infrastructure as Code, we can be confident that two environments will only vary by the values that are passed in through environment variables. If the only difference between two application stacks is the subdomain, then we can expect that everything else about the two applications is similar and that none of the other resources between the two environments will be shared.

XI: Logs
CloudWatch is a great tool for monitoring logs and getting observability with minimal effort.

XII: Admin processes
Run admin/management tasks as one-off processes

Developers will often wish to do one-off administrative or maintenance tasks for the app, such as:

Running database migrations
Running a console
Running one-time scripts committed into the appâ€™s repo
With ECS and CDK, management commands can be run easily either through automation or using a tool called ECS Exec.

To run automated tasks, managementCommandProps can be passed a value of true (false by default). This will run the task each time the application is deployed with cdk deploy. This uses the AWS Custom Resource that is defined in the construct. The CR's onCreate and unUpdate are set to an AwsSdkCall that runs ecs:RunTask with the appropriate parameters.

If you do not want to run database migrations automatically as a Custom Resource in CDK, you can use the AWS CLI to run the command from your CI tool, or you can use ECS Exec.

ECS Exec would also be a good choice if you want to run a one-time script or open a console in the container.

Change nodejs waiting on pipes to not panic (#13689)

<!--- 
Thanks so much for your contribution! If this is your first time
contributing, please ensure that you have read the
[CONTRIBUTING](https://github.com/pulumi/pulumi/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)
documentation.
-->

# Description

<!--- Please include a summary of the change and which issue is fixed.
Please also include relevant motivation and context. -->

Hit this while testing with matrix testing. Fairly frequently the go
routine waiting for `pipesDone` would try to write to the response
channel and panic because it was already closed.

This rewrites the method to only use the response channel for the
running program, and we just explictly wait on all three events (pipes,
handle, program) and return the first one that triggers.

Also it refactors execNodejs to just be a sync method that returns the
response. The management of that running in a goroutine and writing to a
channel is just kept in Run.

commit.message:
Refactor: Move `*Info` objects out of `/pkg/tfbridge` to their own package: `/pkg/tfbridge/info` (#1879)

This PR is a refactor to separate out the user's declaration of a
provider (via `tfbridge.*Info` structs and the runtime behavior of the
provider (via various `tfbridge.*` methods)

This PR moves `/pkg/tfbridge.*Info` and supporting types to
`/pkg/tfbridge/info.*`. This allows finer grain dependency management,
and crucially it allows a package to depend on user information
`/pkg/tfbridge/info` but be importable by the runtime `/pkg/tfbridge`.
To the greatest degree possible, this is a pure refactor. There are 3
unavoidable breaking changes:

1. `tfbridge.MetadataInfo.ExtractRuntimeMetadata` has been moved from a
method on `tfbridge.MetadataInfo` (now `info.Metdata`) to a stand alone
function: `tfbridge.ExtractRuntimeMetadata`. This function is public
only to share with `/pkg/tfgen` and I do not expect users will call it.
A [GH
search](https://github.com/search?q=ExtractRuntimeMetadata+lang%3Ago&type=code)
shows that only the bridge calls this function. I don't expect other
repo to be impacted.
2. `tfbridge.ProviderInfo.(Must)?TraverseProperties` has been moved from
a method to a standalone function: `tfbridge.(Must)?TraverseProperties`.
A [GH code
search](https://github.com/search?q=%28MustTraverseProperties+OR+TraverseProperties%29+lang%3Ago&type=code)
shows that this is only used in `pulumi-gcp`. `pulumi-gcp` is the only
repo I expect to be impacted.
3. `tfbridge.ElementStrategy[T Resource | DataSource] func(tfToken
string, elem *T) error` could not be re-exported since go does not allow
type aliases for generic types. This type is largely internal to the
bridge and a [GH code
search](https://github.com/search?q=tfbridge.ElementStrategy+lang%3Ago&type=code)
does not show any external usage. I don't expect any users to be
effected here.

All other moved types and methods have been back-ported into `tfbridge`
to avoid breaking existing providers. Consumers of the bridge shouldn't
observe any changes, they are welcome to continue to use
`tfbridge.ProviderInfo` and it will continue to work exactly as it
previously did.

This PR consists entirely of name changes. There are no logic changes,
alterations, improvements, etc. The bodies of all functions and types
are unchanged.

Additionally, the dependency array in the `useEffect` hooks is modified to include `data?.id` where applicable, ensuring that the effect runs correctly when the ID changes. These changes enhance code readability and maintainability, aligning with best practices in JavaScript and React development.

The addition of environment variables allows the application to access necessary configuration values during the CI/CD process. Upgrading the GitHub Actions to version 4 ensures that the workflows benefit from the latest features, improvements, and security updates. This change enhances the reliability and performance of the CI/CD processes across all environments (main, production, and staging).

The new GitHub Actions workflow automates the deployment process for the SST application, allowing for easier management of different environments (development and production). The infrastructure files define domain names and stage conditions, enhancing the application's configurability. Refactoring the SST configuration to dynamically load infrastructure files simplifies the deployment process and improves maintainability. The permissions section is now defined at the top level of the workflow file. This change enhances clarity and consistency across the workflow configuration, making it easier to understand the permissions required for the entire job at a glance.

* comment out setting sst config

* ðŸš€ (sst.yaml, package.json): update deployment command to use pnpm for consistency

The deployment command in the GitHub Actions workflow is changed to use `pnpm run deploy`, ensuring consistency with the local development environment. Additionally, the `deploy` script in `package.json` is simplified to remove the hardcoded stage, allowing for more flexible deployments based on the specified stage in the workflow. This change enhances the maintainability and usability of the deployment process.

* ðŸ”§ (sst.yaml): update role-to-assume in GitHub Actions workflow for staging environment
âœ¨ (github.ts): add GitHub OIDC provider and role for AWS IAM integration
â™»ï¸ (dns.ts): remove unnecessary reference path in dns.ts

The role-to-assume in the GitHub Actions workflow is updated to reflect the new role for the staging environment, ensuring proper permissions are granted. A new file is created to define the GitHub OIDC provider and the associated IAM role, allowing for secure access to AWS resources from GitHub Actions. An unnecessary reference path is removed from dns.ts to clean up the code and improve readability.

* ðŸ”§ (github.ts): clean up code by removing unnecessary blank lines and update GitHub role condition to be more specific
The unnecessary blank lines are removed for better readability and to adhere to clean code practices. The condition for the GitHub role is updated to be more specific, allowing access only to the specified repository instead of all repositories under the organization. This enhances security by limiting permissions.

* â™»ï¸ (github.ts, sst.config.ts): refactor GitHub role condition and update AWS profile logic for better clarity and flexibility

The condition for the GitHub role is updated to use a wildcard for repository access, enhancing security by allowing access to all repositories under the specified namespace. Additionally, the AWS profile logic is refactored to accommodate different environments based on the presence of the GITHUB_ACTIONS environment variable, allowing for more flexible deployment configurations.

* update role to assume

* ðŸ”§ (sst.yaml, github.ts, sst.config.ts): update AWS credentials configuration and IAM roles for better environment management
â™»ï¸ (github.ts): refactor GitHub IAM role creation to conditionally include OpenID Connect provider based on stage

The AWS credentials configuration in the GitHub Actions workflow is updated to use the correct roles for the `dev` and `production` branches. The IAM role creation in `github.ts` is refactored to conditionally create the OpenID Connect provider based on the deployment stage. This ensures that the correct permissions are applied based on the environment, enhancing security and maintainability. Additionally, unnecessary comments are removed from `sst.config.ts` to clean up the code.

* ðŸš€ (sst.yaml): update deployment command to use npx for SST deployment
The deployment command is changed to use `npx` to ensure that the correct version of SST is executed, regardless of whether it is installed globally or locally. This enhances the reliability of the deployment process in the GitHub Actions workflow.

* â™»ï¸ (sst.yaml): update GitHub Actions workflow to trigger on main branch instead of production
The workflow condition is changed to trigger on the main branch, aligning with the current branching strategy. This ensures that the correct AWS credentials are configured for deployments, reflecting the latest practices in branch management.

* update production workflow to use arn

* ðŸ”§ (sst.yaml, dns.ts, www.ts, package.json, sst.config.ts): update AWS role assumptions and domain configurations for better flexibility and maintainability
âœ¨ (package.json): add SSO login script for easier AWS access

The AWS role assumptions in the GitHub Actions workflow are now parameterized using environment secrets, enhancing security and flexibility. The domain configurations are refactored to use a root domain constant, improving maintainability. Additionally, a new script for AWS SSO login is added to streamline the authentication process for developers.

* troubleshooting caller identity

* â™»ï¸ (github.ts): refactor OIDC provider creation to check for existence before creating
â¬†ï¸ (package.json): upgrade @pulumi/aws dependency to version 6.58.0

Refactoring the OIDC provider creation logic ensures that the application does not attempt to create a new provider if one already exists, which prevents potential errors and improves efficiency. Upgrading the @pulumi/aws dependency allows for the latest features and bug fixes, enhancing the overall stability and functionality of the infrastructure code.

* ðŸ”§ (sst.yaml, www.ts, sst-env.d.ts): clean up code formatting and improve environment handling

The changes include removing unnecessary spaces in the role-to-assume strings in the GitHub Actions workflow file, ensuring consistency and preventing potential issues. In the `www.ts` file, the redirects are now conditionally set based on the application stage, allowing for more flexible behavior in different environments. The `sst-env.d.ts` file has been updated to remove the unused resource definition, streamlining the codebase and improving maintainability.

* ðŸ”§ (sst.yaml): update role-to-assume for GitHub Actions to use production role
âœ¨ (sst-env.d.ts): add AppilyAdvanceSite resource definition for Next.js application

The role-to-assume in the GitHub Actions workflow is updated to point to the production role, ensuring that the correct permissions are used during deployment. Additionally, a new resource definition for the AppilyAdvanceSite is added to the TypeScript declaration file, allowing for better type safety and integration with the Next.js application in the SST framework.

* trigger pull request

* add environments

* trigger pull request2

* add installing of pnpm

* âœ¨ (dns.ts): add outputs object to export FrontendUrl for www subdomain
The new outputs object provides a structured way to access the FrontendUrl for the www subdomain. This change enhances the clarity and usability of the DNS configuration, making it easier to reference the frontend URL in other parts of the application.

* add https

* â™»ï¸ (previews.yaml, dns.ts): refactor outputs structure to simplify FrontendUrl assignment
The outputs structure in `dns.ts` is simplified by directly assigning the `FrontendUrl` to the `www` key. This change reduces complexity and improves readability. The corresponding update in `previews.yaml` ensures that the new structure is correctly referenced, allowing for a more straightforward extraction of the `FRONTEND_URL`.

* âœ¨ (clear-preview.yaml): add GitHub Actions workflow to destroy preview environments on pull request closure
â™»ï¸ (previews.yaml): remove redundant Node.js setup and AWS identity fetch steps from the preview deployment workflow
The new workflow `clear-preview.yaml` automates the destruction of preview environments when a pull request is closed, ensuring that resources are cleaned up efficiently. The changes in `previews.yaml` streamline the deployment process by removing unnecessary steps, improving the overall efficiency of the CI/CD pipeline.

* add pnpm install

* ðŸ”§ (GitHub Actions): replace manual AWS credentials setup with aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials for better security and maintainability

The manual setup of AWS credentials has been replaced with the `aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials` action across multiple workflows. This change enhances security by avoiding hardcoded credentials and simplifies the configuration process. The use of environment variables for the AWS account ID allows for a more flexible and secure setup, making it easier to manage credentials across different environments.

* ðŸ”§ (clear-preview.yaml): add condition to skip job for PRs from dev to main
The workflow now includes a condition to skip the entire job if a pull request is made from the 'dev' branch to the 'main' branch. This change prevents unnecessary job executions for specific PRs, optimizing the CI/CD process and reducing resource usage.

* add conditional

* remove paths from feature workflow

* add   workflow_dispatch

* âœ¨ (GitHub Actions): add clear-feature workflow to destroy feature environments after PR closure
â™»ï¸ (GitHub Actions): refactor feature-branch workflow to remove duplicate AWS credentials configuration

The new `clear-feature.yaml` workflow automates the cleanup of feature environments when a pull request is closed and merged into the `dev` branch. This helps maintain a clean environment and reduces resource usage. Additionally, the AWS credentials configuration has been refactored in the `feature-branch.yaml` workflow to avoid duplication, improving maintainability and reducing potential errors.

* remove condition
